fields.descriptive_line: part; French, 1500-1550, oak, floral, cartouche. Ex Peyre Collection.
fields.physical_description:
Oak muntin (upright framing piece) probably from a cupboard front. 

A single piece of oak, vertically grained, cut at both top and bottom with a wide tenon with mitred shoulders (at the top). Each tenon pierced with two large peg holes and a smaller, countersunk hole in the centre that appear to have been added later as a fixing point for display. Both sides are cut at the front with a quarter-round moulding, and a continuous, square groove in which panels would have been held. The front surface, inset between squared edges is carved in low relief with a ribbon loop from which is suspended a plant (possibly the leaf and seed head of columbine - Aquilegia spp., or rosehip, or tulip), superimposed at the bottom over a raised band in a variant of Greek key pattern. The back is plain but for a lump of dried red paste or wax.
fields.dimensions: Height: 32 cm, Width: 11 cm, Thickness: 3.6 cm
fields.location: Furniture, room 133, case BY9, shelf LEDGE1
fields.public_access_description:
This fragment of Renaissance furniture is a muntin (upright framing piece). It probably came from a cupboard front, where it would have separated floating panels on either side. Each tenon at top and bottom (pierced for wooden pegs) secured it into mortises in adjacent framing pieces. The low-relief carved ornament of stylised leaves and berries or seeds, perhaps rose hips, tulip or columbine are typical of Renaissance ornament used in northern France about 1550.

This panel was formerly in the collection of Emile Peyre (1824-1904), a notable Parisian collector of French medieval and Renaissance artefacts. In 1895 the South Kensington Museum (renamed the V&A in 1899), bought over 300 pieces of furniture and woodwork from him (as well as sculpture and metalwork), at a cost of £11,878. 16s. 9d.
fields.history_note:
Bought from Emile Peyre, apparently for £3.

In the V&A Peyre papers, this muntin (and another of the same size ('slightly split') written off) is listed in T. Armstrong's typed Inventory of the Peyre Collection (c.March 1895) as no. 291 '2 Fragments of styles, 4 1/2 in. x 9 1/2 in; renaissance ornament. £3?', and listed in the space I on the plan, being the back passage behind the staircase, overlooking the garden on the ground floor.

This panel was formerly in the collection of Emile Peyre (1824-1904), a notable Parisian collector of French medieval and renaissance artefacts. In 1895 the South Kensington Museum (renamed the V&A in 1900), bought over 300 pieces of furniture and woodwork from him, (as well as sculpture and metalwork), at a cost of £11,878. 16s. 9d.

Mounted in a glazed Circulation frame with 153a-1897 and 988-1900 (removed from frame Feb. 2011)
